recode to exclude the mixed/intermediate state "3" -- note that for all word order features involving two elements, feature states denoting no dominant order are excluded rather than binarized so as not to massively boost the weight of word order in the full dataset. Most languages do have a dominant word oder.

expectation.tested: prepositions OR postpositions
IF NO adpositions, THEN morphological case
motivation.for.test: We expect most languages to use either adpositions or non-core case to mark oblique arguments, so that a lack of adpositions will correlate with the presence of (non-core) morphological case

expectation.tested: IF agreement with noun in gender, THEN agreement with noun in number
motivation.for.test: Gender is less common than number overall, and if you agree with the uncommon thing (gender) you are likely to agree with the common thing (number); cf Greenberg 1963 U36 (extension)

expectation.tested: IF agreement of article with noun, THEN agreement of demonstrative with noun
motivation.for.test: Articles frequently historically derive from demonstratives, and demonstratives are more common in languages overall, so we expect the properties of articles to frequently be a subset of the properties of demonstratives

expectation.tested: IF agreement of attributives with noun, THEN agreement of demonstrative with noun
motivation.for.test: Attributive agreement is less common than demonstrative agreement, so we expect agreement with the more common case (demonstratives) when it is present in the less common case (attributives)

expectation.tested: morphological OR phonologically free antipassive
motivation.for.test: Note this relationship is near-logical given the rareness of antipassive constructions and that extended exponence was possibly not searched for
resulting.modification: merging, exclusion of both and neither (feature1 vs. feature2)

expectation.tested: IF instrumental applicative marker, THEN benefactive applicative marker
motivation.for.test: Benefactives are more common (give, write to, etc) than the use of instrumental applicatives, so we expect instrumental applicatives to be a later addition to a large set of valence changing operations. Also, according to WALS chapter 109, it is common for the same applicative morpheme to be used for both benefactives and instruments, while dedicated instrumental applicatives are rare

expectation.tested: IF locative or directional marking on the verb, THEN benefactive applicative marker
motivation.for.test: According to WALS chapter 109, it is common for the same applicative morpheme to be used for both benefactives and locatives, while dedicated locative applicatives are rare

expectation.tested: IF locative or directional applicative marker, THEN verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones
motivation.for.test: Applicatives are valency changing mechanisms and they can turn intransitive verbs into transitive if applicable to intransitive verbs

expectation.tested: IF benefactive applicative marker, THEN verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones
motivation.for.test: Applicatives are valency changing mechanisms and they can turn intransitive verbs into transitive if applicable to intransitive verbs

expectation.tested: IF instrumental applicative marker, THEN verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones
motivation.for.test: Applicatives are valency changing mechanisms and they can turn intransitive verbs into transitive if applicable to intransitive verbs

expectation.tested: IF locative or directional marking on the verb, THEN causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs (if verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones)
IF locative or directional marking on the verb, THEN causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs
motivation.for.test: Causatives are more common than applicatives, so we expect applicatives to be a later addition to the set of valence changing operations
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: IF benefactive applicative marker, THEN causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs (if verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones)
IF benefactive applicative marker, THEN causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs
motivation.for.test: Causatives are more common than applicatives, so we expect applicatives to be a later addition to the set of valence changing operations
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: IF NO causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs (if verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones), THEN NO benefactive applicative marker
IF NO causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs, THEN NO benefactive applicative marker
motivation.for.test: Causatives are the most common way of adding an argument, and applicatives are less common. Thus, if a language lacks the common argument-adding morphological strategy (a morphological causative), then it is unlikely to have the less common argument-adding morphological strategy (a morphological applicative)
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: IF NO causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs (if verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones), THEN NO instrumental applicative marker
IF NO causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs, THEN NO instrumental applicative marker
motivation.for.test: Causatives are more common than applicatives, so we expect applicatives to be a later addition to the set of valence changing operations.
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: IF indefinite article, THEN definite article
motivation.for.test: cf Becker 2021, Chapter 9

expectation.tested: prenominal article OR postnominal article
motivation.for.test: Most of the time we expect all articles to be in the same position in a language, cf category clustering (Mansfield et al., 2020)

expectation.tested: IF attributes behave as verbs when used attributively, THEN they behave as verbs when used predicatively
motivation.for.test: We expect attributives to have consistent part-of-speech properties, but we also expect when many parts of speech are used predicatively, they acquire verbal properties. Thus, verbal properties in an attributive position should imply verbal properties in a predicative position.

expectation.tested: IF adnominal property words can be discontinuous, THEN morphological case
motivation.for.test: The GB026 chapter description details that languages that allow for discontinuous adnominal property words typically show extensive agreement systems, which can be expressed by gender and/or mophological case

expectation.tested: IF adnominal property words can be discontinuous, THEN gender (conditioned on number)
IF adnominal property words can be discontinuous, THEN gender
motivation.for.test: The GB026 chapter description details that languages that allow for discontinuous adnominal property words typically show extensive agreement systems, which can be expressed by gender and/or mophological case
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: IF adnominal property words can be discontinuous, THEN adnominal property word can agree with the noun at all (in gender/noun class and/or number)
motivation.for.test: The GB026 chapter description details that languages that allow for discontinuous adnominal property words typically show extensive agreement systems, which can be expressed by gender and/or mophological case and/or number

expectation.tested: IF non-pronominal case for arguments, THEN pronominal case for arguments
motivation.for.test: Many languages have morphological case only for pronouns, while having morphological case only for nouns is rare

expectation.tested: IF case for core arguments, THEN case for oblique arguments
motivation.for.test: Many languages have morphological case only for oblique arguments. Having morphological case only for core arguments is rare

expectation.tested: IF demonstrative classifiers, THEN numeral classifiers
motivation.for.test: Numeral classifiers are the most common type of classifier

expectation.tested: classifiers OR nominal gender (conditioned on number)
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: yes, but only for one of the OR dimensions, tendency logged in known.remaining.dependencies

expectation.tested: classifiers OR nominal gender
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: clause chaining OR serial verb construction
motivation.for.test: Serial verb constructions are defined in Grambank as only coordinating the verb, while clause chaining coordinates clauses. We expect most languages to have one strategy or the other
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: yes, but only for one of the OR dimensions, tendency logged in known.remaining.dependencies

expectation.tested: IF verb-initial, THEN no copula
surpass/exceed OR locational (corresponding state from merged feature)
f2.equals.for.test: marker of standard with elsewhere locational meaning

expectation.tested: surpass/exceed OR locational
motivation.for.test: Single strategy may be expected
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also.

expectation.tested: surpass/exceed OR standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning
motivation.for.test: Single strategy may be expected

expectation.tested: comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning (corresponding state from merged feature) OR comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning
f1.equals.for.test: marker of standard with elsewhere locational meaning

expectation.tested: comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning OR comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning
motivation.for.test: Single strategy may be expected
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also.

expectation.tested: bound degree marker OR non-bound degree marker
motivation.for.test: Single strategy may be expected
resulting.modification: merging, exclusion of both and neither (feature1 vs. feature2)

expectation.tested: comparative degree marker on property word OR comparative construction with form elsewhere meaning surpass/exceed
motivation.for.test: We expect the degree notion to be expressed once in a comparative construction. Of course, it is possible for a language to have multiple comparison constructions, and in this case, the association would be weakened.

expectation.tested: comparative construction with form elsewhere meaning locational OR conjoined
motivation.for.test: different states in WALS chapter 121
resulting.modification: merging, exclusion of both (neither vs. feature1 vs. feature2)

expectation.tested: comparative construction with form elsewhere meaning neither locational nor surpass/exceed OR conjoined  (corresponding state from merged feature)
f2.unequals.for.test: neither, marker of standard with elsewhere locational meaning

expectation.tested: comparative construction with form elsewhere meaning neither locational nor surpass/exceed OR conjoined
motivation.for.test: different states in WALS chapter 121
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also.

expectation.tested: comparative construction with form elsewhere meaning surpass/exceed OR conjoined (corresponding state from merged feature)
f2.unequals.for.test: neither, marker of standard with elsewhere locational meaning

expectation.tested: comparative construction with form elsewhere meaning surpass/exceed OR conjoined
motivation.for.test: different states in WALS chapter 121
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also.

expectation.tested: conparative degree marker on property word OR conjoined (corresponding state from merged feature)
f2.unequals.for.test: neither, marker of standard with elsewhere locational meaning

expectation.tested: conparative degree marker on property word OR conjoined
motivation.for.test: different states in WALS chapter 121
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also.

expectation.tested: IF verb compounding, THEN serial verb constructions
motivation.for.test: Verb compounding is sometimes called a serial verb construction, and the two can be easily confused. In addition, serial verbs can diachronically lead to verb compounding, so we expect a correlation

expectation.tested: IF verb compounding, THEN morphological TAM
motivation.for.test: Verb incorporation is typically a feature of highly polysynthetic languages which also mark other grammatical information synthetically. We expect it to be unusual to have verb incorporation (which is a relatively rare, highly synthetic feature) without marking grammatical information like TAM or SAP on the verb (which is relatively common, even with moderately synthetic languages)

expectation.tested: IF noun incorporation, THEN morphological TAM
motivation.for.test: Noun incorporation is typically a feature of highly polysynthetic languages which also mark other grammatical information synthetically. We expect it to be unusual to have noun incorporation (which is a relatively rare, highly synthetic feature) without marking grammatical information like TAM or SAP on the verb (which is relatively common, even with moderately synthetic languages).

expectation.tested: complementizer of think/know either preposed OR postposed
motivation.for.test: Single strategy may be expected
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: yes, but only for one of the OR dimensions, tendency logged in known.remaining.dependencies

expectation.tested: IF causatives formed by affixes or clitics, THEN verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones
motivation.for.test: Causatives are valence operations that add an argument. If they are present as affixes, we expect affixes to be able to turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones.

expectation.tested: IF elevation, THEN three or more distances in demonstratives
motivation.for.test: Elevation distinctions in demonstratives are rare, such that elaborate demonstrative systems are expected generally if elevation distctions are present

expectation.tested: IF visible-invisible, THEN three or more distances in demonstratives
motivation.for.test: Visibility distinctions in demonstratives are relatively rare, such that elaborate demonstrative systems are expected generally if visibility distctions are present

expectation.tested: IF augmentative marking, THEN diminutive marking also
motivation.for.test: Diminutives are more common than augmentatives.

expectation.tested: either diminutive/augmentative by nominal classification OR diminutive/augmentative affix
motivation.for.test: Single strategy may be expected
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: yes, but only for one of the OR dimensions, tendency logged in known.remaining.dependencies

expectation.tested: IF gender in nouns (conditioned on number), THEN gender in pronouns
IF gender in nouns, THEN gender in pronouns
motivation.for.test: cf Greenberg 1963 U43
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: marking on possessor (conditioned on case) OR marking on possessed (conditioned on SAP)
marking on possessor OR marking on possessed
motivation.for.test: Single strategy may be expected
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: IF marking on possessed, THEN SAP-indexing on verb (if morphological TAM present)
IF marking on possessed, THEN SAP-indexing on verb
motivation.for.test: We can expect that there is a tendency for head-marking across verbs and nouns
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: verb modification (conditioned on morphological TAM) OR auxiliary verb for standard negation
motivation.for.test: Single strategy may be expected

expectation.tested: verb modification for negation OR auxiliary particle for negation
motivation.for.test: Single strategy may be expected

expectation.tested: auxiliary verb OR auxiliary particle
motivation.for.test: Single strategy may be expected

expectation.tested: negation clause-final OR clause-initial
motivation.for.test: Single strategy may be expected

expectation.tested: IF same negator to all, THEN copula for nominal predication
motivation.for.test: If a verbal negator can be used with all other predicative types (locational, existential, nominal), then we expect a verbal copula. However, in GB117 non-verbal copulas are also included. Also for a TRUE to GB140 all negators need to be identical. These coding choices may weaken the proposed correlation

expectation.tested: IF there is a difference between imperative and declarative negation constructions, THEN there is mood
motivation.for.test: Negation is closely related to irrealis mood. If there is a distinction between types of negation with differing sentential force, there is probably mood distinction in the language

expectation.tested: IF standard negation can be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb, THEN there is morphological TAM
motivation.for.test: Negation is close to mood marking and unlikely to be the only marking on the verb without other morphological TAM-components.

expectation.tested: IF singular marked in NPs, THEN plural in NPs
IF dual in NPs, THEN plural in NPs
motivation.for.test: Greenberg 1963 U34

expectation.tested: IF dual marking in NPs (conditioned on plural in NPs at all), THEN dual marking in pronouns
motivation.for.test: WALS chapter 35

expectation.tested: IF trial in NPs, THEN dual in NPs
motivation.for.test: Greenberg 1963 U34

expectation.tested: IF paucal in NPs (conditioned on trials not being present), THEN plural in NPs
IF paucal in NPs, THEN plural in NPs
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: phonologically free number in NPs (conditioned on plural marking in NPs) OR morphological number in NPs (conditioned on plural marking in NPs)
phonologically free number in NPs OR morphological number in NPs
motivation.for.test: different states in WALS chapter 33
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also.

expectation.tested: IF phonologically free number marking of NPs at all, THEN plural in NPs
IF morphological number marking of nouns at all, THEN plural in NPs
IF associative plural, THEN number in NPs
trial (conditioned on dual) OR paucal in NPs
trial OR paucal in NPs
motivation.for.test: We expect that languages will not resort to encoding both trial and paucal number, because trial number would most likely be subsumed under the paucal category.
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also.

expectation.tested: IF non-phonological allomorphy of number markers, THEN gender/noun classes
motivation.for.test: If there are different number markers for nouns, it is probably because there is gender distinction between nouns

expectation.tested: IF non-phonological allomorphy of number markers, THEN gender/noun classes
motivation.for.test: If there are different number markers for nouns, it is probably because there is gender distinction between nouns
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: IF gender, THEN number
motivation.for.test: cf Greenberg 1963, U36

expectation.tested: decimal OR body-part-tallying
motivation.for.test: The use of body parts to count numbers is not expected to coincide with counting on fingers (the origin of base 10); multiple systems are more likely associated with context, not captured in grammars
resulting.modification: merging, exclusion of both (neither vs. feature1 vs. feature2)

expectation.tested: IF elements of quinary numeral system, THEN decimal

expectation.tested: IF adnominal possession is coded on the possessor, THEN case
motivation.for.test: Coding on the possessor is frequently genitive, so we expect many of these languages to have case marking, at a minimum for genitives (obliques)

expectation.tested: IF predicative possession of type locative, THEN oblique case on NP
motivation.for.test: If you have possession with a locative, it is likely a case-marked locative, which is used elsewhere outside of possession.

expectation.tested: IF predicative possession of type dative, THEN oblique case on NP
motivation.for.test: If predicative possession uses a dative, it is probably a case marked dative. If so, this means the language has a dative which it uses elsewhere

expectation.tested: IF predicative possession of type adnominal possesor, THEN oblique case on NP
motivation.for.test: An adnominal possessor is typically a genitive, which is definitionally an oblique case marker. Most languages with such constructions will have genitives in this position

expectation.tested: IF special adnominal possessive pronouns, THEN case in pronouns
motivation.for.test: Adnominal possessive pronouns are typically genitives, and languages with genitives typically have other case-marking. Genitives arising without other cases in a language are rare

expectation.tested: IF male/female distinction in 2nd person pronoun, THEN male/female distinction in 3rd person too
motivation.for.test: Languages that have a distinction in 1st person while they do not have a gender distinction in 3rd person are most probably languages with genderlects (Rose 2018). There is also a well-known hierarchy that grammatical gender distinctions are much more common in 3rd person, then 2nd person and finally 1st person. (Cysouw 2003, Corbett 1991)

expectation.tested: IF male/female distinction in 1st person pronoun, THEN male/female distinction in 3rd person
motivation.for.test: cf Greenberg 1963, U44. Languages that have a distinction in 2nd person while they do not have a gender distinction in 3rd person are most probably languages with genderlects (Rose 2018). There is also a well-known hierarchy that grammatical gender distinctions are much more common in 3rd person, then 2nd person and finally 1st person.

expectation.tested: IF male/female distinction in 1st person pronoun, THEN male/female distinction in 2nd person
motivation.for.test: cf Greenberg 1963, U44. There is a well-known hierarchy that grammatical gender distinctions are much more common in 3rd person, then 2nd person and finally 1st person

expectation.tested: IF pro-drop/null anaphora, THEN SAP-indexing (if morphological TAM present)
motivation.for.test: The GB522 chapter description elaborates that pro-drop is not mutually exclusive with S/A indexing, approximated by SAP-indexing here

expectation.tested: IF infixation at all, THEN affixal SAP-indexing and/or morphological TAM-marking
motivation.for.test: Infixing is rare, and whenever it exists it typically coexists with non-infixing affixation. SAP-indexing and morphological TAM-marking act as a proxy for all affixes.

expectation.tested: IF verb carries a marker of animacy of argument, THEN SAP-indexing on verb (if morphological TAM present)
IF verb carries a marker of animacy of argument, THEN SAP-indexing on verb
motivation.for.test: Variations in SAP-indexing due to animacy are unexpected where there is no SAP-indexing

expectation.tested: IF verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant, THEN SAP-indexing on the verb (if morphological TAM present)
IF verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant, THEN SAP-indexing on the verb
motivation.for.test: Verb stem alternation by core participant necessarily means SAP-indexing on the stem alternating verb. We expect languages with such irregular marking of SAP to also have regular SAP indexing

expectation.tested: IF verb suppletion for participant number, THEN SAP-indexing on the verb (if morphological TAM present)
IF verb suppletion for participant number, THEN SAP-indexing on the verb
motivation.for.test: Verb suppletion for participant number is a limited way of indexing and we expect it to co-exist with regular indexation

expectation.tested: IF conjugation classes, THEN morphological SAP- and/or TAM-marking
motivation.for.test: Conjugation classes are most typically verbs that differ by agreement and by TAM. Therefore we expect most conjugation classes to occur in languages that have SAP and/or TAM marked on the verb.

expectation.tested: IF phonologically bound reflexive/reciprocal marker on the verb, THEN SAP-indexing on the verb (if morphological TAM present)
motivation.for.test: Reflexive/reciprocal markers are a form of indexing the A and P roles, so we expect a language with reflexive/reciprocal markers to index SAP in other ways

expectation.tested: IF phonologically bound reflexive/reciprocal marker on the verb, THEN SAP-indexing on the verb
motivation.for.test: Reflexive/reciprocal markers are a form of indexing the A and P roles, so we expect a language with reflexive/reciprocal markers to index SAP in other ways

expectation.tested: IF SAP-indexing, THEN TAM-indexing
motivation.for.test: Greenberg 1963, U30

expectation.tested: IF variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions, THEN morphological TAM-marking
motivation.for.test: For variation strategies to vary on account of TAM distinctions, TAM distinctions need to exist, of which morphological TAM-marking is the best proxy for

expectation.tested: IF variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes, THEN SAP-indexing via affixes (if morphological TAM present)
IF variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes, THEN SAP-indexing via affixes
motivation.for.test: Changes in position we assume are rare, while changes by morphological marking are driving the variations based on verb class distinctions. We therefore assume variations in marking are typically associated with SAP marking
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: IF variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions, THEN SAP-indexing via affixes (if morphological TAM present)

motivation.for.test: Changes in position we assume are rare, while changes by morphological marking are driving the variations based on person distinctions. We therefore assume variations in marking are typically associated with SAP marking

expectation.tested: IF inverse morphologically marked on verb, THEN SAP-indexing on verb (if morphological TAM present)
IF inverse morphologically marked on verb, THEN SAP-indexing on verb
motivation.for.test: Inverse markers are typically used in tandem with SAP indexing and markers would typically not be analysed as inverse without person markers.
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: IF morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states, THEN S-indexing on verb
motivation.for.test: Marking of controlled and uncontrolled events is related to indexing of a split-S system, which is almost always linked to S indexing on the verb (see S-SAP-16)

expectation.tested: IF there is switch reference, THEN S-indexing on the verb
motivation.for.test: Switch reference systems are typically on the verb and distinguish subjects, so we expect S-indexing on the verb as well.

expectation.tested: IF there is verb suppletion for tense or aspect, THEN morphological TAM marking on the verb
motivation.for.test: Suppletion for tense or aspect usually correlate with a productive category of verbal TAM, which implies marking on the verb.

expectation.tested: IF there is switch reference, THEN pro-drop (conditioned on SAP)
IF there is switch reference, THEN pro-drop
motivation.for.test: Switch reference encodes the presence of a different subject than the previous clause; we expect this to co-occur with the absence of an overt NP referring to the argument (in which case the change in reference would be obvious)
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: IF suppletion in give, THEN tense aspect suppletion (conditioned on T/A and morphological TAM)
motivation.for.test: We expect tense aspect suppletion to drive suppletion patterns, so suppletion in 'give' is probably of the tense aspect variety

expectation.tested: IF suppletion in see, THEN tense aspect suppletion (conditioned on T/A and morphological TAM)
motivation.for.test: We expect tense aspect suppletion to drive suppletion patterns, so suppletion in 'see' is probably of the tense aspect variety

expectation.tested: IF suppletion in come, THEN tense aspect suppletion (conditioned on T/A and morphological TAM)
motivation.for.test: We expect tense aspect suppletion to drive suppletion patterns, so suppletion in 'come' is probably of the tense aspect variety

expectation.tested: IF direct evidence, THEN indirect evidence
IF present tense, THEN past tense
motivation.for.test: In tense marking, the present tense is very typically the unmarked one. So if it is marked overtly, then more common tenses will be too.

expectation.tested: IF past tense, THEN future tense
IF there is a productive morphological pattern for deriving object noun from verb, THEN there is a productive morphological pattern for deriving agent noun from verb
motivation.for.test: Agentive derivations are more common, so we expect languages to have the more common pattern (deriving an agent) if they have the less common pattern (deriving an object)

expectation.tested: IF there is a productive morphological pattern for deriving object noun from verb, THEN there is a productive morphological pattern for deriving action noun from verb
motivation.for.test: Action derivations are more common, so we expect languages to have the more common pattern (deriving action) if they have the less common pattern (deriving an object)

expectation.tested: IF there is a productive morphological pattern for deriving object noun from verb, THEN there is a productive morphological pattern for deriving action noun from verb
motivation.for.test: Action derivations are more common, so we expect languages to have the more common pattern (deriving action) if they have the less common pattern (deriving an object)
statistical.action.or.logging.necessary: this test involves a feature that is modified due to statistical conditioning; the corresponding test with the conditioned feature is performed also

expectation.tested: action nominalization AND agent nominalization
motivation.for.test: Action and agent nominalizations are very common. Languages with nominalization may be expected to have both strategies.

expectation.tested: IF 100 or less verb roots, THEN light-verb constructions
motivation.for.test: There are more than 100 event conceptualizations, and light-verb constructions create events from nouns with a light verb. We expect languages with small verb inventories to create more events using light verb constructions
